greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Suppose n=(p1^e1)(p2^e2)... where p1,p2,... are the prime numbers and e1,e2,... are nonnegative integers. Then a(n) = e1 + (e2)*n + (e3)*(n^2) + (e4)*(n^3) + ... + (ek)*(n^(k-1)) + ...
comment: Replace "(ek)*(n^(k-1))" with "(ek)*(x^(k-1))" for all k and extend the definition of a to positive rationals and a becomes an isomorphism between positive rationals under multiplication and polynomials over Z under addition. This remark generalizes A001222, A048675 and A054841: evaluate said polynomial at x=1, x=2 and x=10, respectively.
reference: Joseph J. Rotman, The Theory of Groups: An Introduction, 2nd ed. Boston: Allyn and Bacon, Inc. 1973. Page 9, problem 1.26.
link: Sam Alexander, Post to sci.math. [Broken link]
program: (PARI) a(n) = my(f = factor(n)); sum(k=1, #f~, f[k,2]*n^(primepi(f[k,1])-1)); \\ _Michel Marcus_, Nov 01 2016
results.author: _Sam Alexander_, Dec 12 2003
